title: Update CHANGELOG and crate version to 0.30.0
Create new MemoryRefreshKind type and new `System::refresh_memory_specifics` method
Remove need for self for a few System methods
Make Process::tasks method available on all platforms and change its return type to `Option`
Inline tasks at the same level as other processes
body:
It allows to simplify the handling of processes in linux while also improving parallel computations.

Needed for #1133.

title: Update crate version and CHANGELOG to 0.29.11
Correctly handle where group name is NULL
body:
Fixes https://github.com/GuillaumeGomez/sysinfo/issues/1154.

In the new version, the code has been re-written and the check is already in place, so nothing to do for 0.30.

title: Replace REMAINING_FILES static mut with Atomic
body: This removes some unsafe code and a clippy allow, I used the strongest Ordering (`SeqCst`) when the operation ordering mattered and used `Relaxed` when it doesn't, although could swap it to `SeqCst` if you want.

title: add the netdevs feature for the optional bring back of NFS
body:
This brings NFS back, but only as an optional feature called `netdevs`.

Why `netdevs`? Because when CIFS is mounted with the **hard** option, it would cause the same hang as NFS. The only difference is that NFS is hard by default and CIFS is soft by default. So in my option it makes more sense to disable both by default, but enable them with feature if users have no problem with the risk.

More details about the issues with mounting NFS: https://github.com/GuillaumeGomez/sysinfo/issues/842#issuecomment-1815859527

title: Fix endless loop in `get_user_groups`
body:
Fixes  #1145.

Can you confirm it fixes the issue for you @aw-cf please?

title: Bump MSRV to 1.65
Change `Disk::file_system()` to return `&OsStr`
body:
As discussed in #1105, this PR changes the public interface `Disk::file_system()` to return an `&OsStr` instead of a `&[u8]`.

(I've decided to move the MSRV change into a separate PR #1108 because there is really no connection between these two PRs)

title: win: enumerate drives via FindNextVolumeW + GetVolumePathNamesForVolumeNameW
body:
This PR changes the mechanism for enumerating "disks" on windows. The previous approach only worked for volumes that were assigned a drive letter. Windows volumes can also be mounted in the file system.

We first fetch a list of volume GUID paths (volume names). These have the form `\\?\{xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx}\`. We then use `GetVolumePathNamesForVolumeNameW` to map each of these to a set of mount paths (`C:\` for drive letters or arbitrary paths for path mounts). We then return one `Disk` entry for each mount path (flat-map).

This should roughly match the semantics of the linux implementation, which also primarily looks at mount points (not actual disk volumes). It means that a volume that is mounted multiple times (multiple drive letters and/or mount paths) will show up as multiple disks.

The output of the simple example changes as follows:
Before:
```
> disks
Disk("")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: SSD][removable: no] mounted on "C:\\": 6045496340480/8000072638464 B
Disk("User")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: HDD][removable: no] mounted on "F:\\": 724046233600/3000457228288 B
Disk("Quick")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: SSD][removable: no] mounted on "Q:\\": 262496968704/2000381014016 B
```
After:
```
> disks
Disk("Hot")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: SSD][removable: no] mounted on "C:\\Hot\\": 606733127680/2048390066176 B
Disk("User")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: HDD][removable: no] mounted on "F:\\": 724046233600/3000457228288 B
Disk("User")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: HDD][removable: no] mounted on "C:\\Cold\\": 724046233600/3000457228288 B
Disk("")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: SSD][removable: no] mounted on "C:\\": 6043730104320/8000072638464 B
Disk("Quick")[FS: ['N', 'T', 'F', 'S']][Type: SSD][removable: no] mounted on "Q:\\": 262496968704/2000381014016 B
```

I did check the impact on `cargo bench` on my machine
```
origin/master:
test bench_refresh_disks_list      ... bench:     129,725 ns/iter (+/- 5,296)

windows-disks-mount-path:
test bench_refresh_disks_list      ... bench:     250,926 ns/iter (+/- 9,357)
```

I did a quick trace with the Windows Performance Recorder and it seems to me like all the time gets spent in `GetVolumePathNamesForVolumeNameW`. Seems like that's the price to pay here. Below is a screenshot of one of the bench threads. 
![image](https://github.com/GuillaumeGomez/sysinfo/assets/149009/77d3b9ea-f034-4913-ab59-c94ff6340ffc)

# Contribution
I noticed that the Nushell [`sys` command](https://github.com/nushell/nushell/blob/d0dc6986dd14e7ea5443f3dc0eb5b101c5de5efc/crates/nu-command/src/system/sys.rs#L108) did not list mount paths and traced the omission to this crate. It seemed like a fine excuse to write some "low level" systems code and try out the `windows` crate.

I do realize that this is 100% a drive-by PR and that the feature is _relatively_ exotic. If you don't think the PR is a good fit for the crate, please do feel free to close it without comment 😄 . I learned a lot in the process and getting the PR merged would just be a little bonus on top. That said, if you _are_ interested in the PR, I'm happy to work on it 😄

title: Remove `sort_by` methods and rename getters into `list` and `list_mut`
Add missing warning for Windows support for `System::load_average`
Correctly retrieve process root directory on mac
fix: refresh process memory on Windows on first update
body:
The first time a process is refreshed on windows, its memory values are not fetched. This is only done on a second refresh.

Fix this my moving the refresh memory into the process update function so that it is called
everytime the process is updated.

Fixes #1084

title: Use `crate::` for local items and add extra information on global CPU
Allow to only refresh CPU info in example and correctly parse /proc/cpuinfo file
body: Follow-up of #1075 which wrongly updated this information.

title: Fix `serialize_struct` field count and add a comment to prevent forgetting about it again
Add missing checks for NULL pointers
Fix invalid name retrieval for linux CPU and remove frequency, brand and vendor ID from global CPU
Windows: Fix invalid use of NULL pointer
body:
As nicely pointed out [here](https://github.com/GuillaumeGomez/sysinfo/pull/950#issuecomment-1732376879), `sysinfo` was using pointers without checking if they were NULL first.

cc @poliorcetics

title: add basics os&cpu information to C interface and example
body:
- fixed: build c interface failed on Windows
- add: some functions to get basics OS&CPU information

title: serde.rs: fix serialize_struct field counts
body:
Some of the serializers used incorrect (too small) field counts when serializing structures. This commit/PR fixes that.

This is not an issue when using JSON serializer which doesn't need the length field to operate correctly [0] but it could be an issue if a different serializer would be used in the future which would rely on the length field [1].

[0] https://github.com/serde-rs/json/blob/b6e113f2036c52e994ca805e530ee4ffae791f71/src/value/ser.rs#L262-L277
[1] https://grep.app/search?q=fn%20serialize_map%28self%2C%20len%3A%20Option%3Cusize%3E%29%20-%3E%20Result%3CSelf%3A%3ASerial

title: Move unix platforms into the same folder to move the unix files into it as well
Update CHANGELOG and crate version to 0.29.10
Fix memory limits to only use cgroups values if they're sensible
body:
As discussed in #1054 , there is an issue that occurs when the cgroups memory limits are higher than the actual system memory amount. The cgroups value is used instead, even though that amount of memory is not actually available. The solution is to use the minimum value of the total memory reported by /proc/meminfo and the cgroups value. The easiest way to accomplish this is to hoist the cgroups checks out of the `read_table` call; this was needlessly invoking the cgroups logics once per line in the meminfo table. By moving it out of the call we do it once, after the table has been processed, and we can properly consider which value we actually want to use.  Most of the changes here are whitespace; the new logic is on lines 290 and 313 (using the minimum of the mem_total and the cgroups value) and 291 and 314 (using the newly assigned variable instead of the cgroups value when calculating mem_free).

This change passes the test suite on a VM with the unusual cgroups configuration that was described in the issue.

title: src: linux: cpu: Add debug in public CpuValues
Update CHANGELOG and crate version to 0.29.9
Fix cgroups always being ignored when refreshing memory
body: This solves the newline issue I described in #954, though the disk issue probably remains (and the memory issue might also remain specifically for LXC, I don't know how it sets up its cgroups).

title: Update CHANGELOG and crate version to 0.29.8
Move CPU-related code into cpu.rs file for freebsd
Move CPU-related code into cpu.rs file for macOS
Update CHANGELOG and crate version for 0.29.7
Fix: windows process name in 0.29.6 are broken
linux/memory: Add cgroups v1 and v2 support
Get CPU frequency on mac M1
body:
Fixes https://github.com/GuillaumeGomez/sysinfo/issues/872.

How to test it:

```
$ cargo run --example simple
     Running `target/debug/examples/simple`
Getting processes' information...
Done.
To get the commands' list, enter 'help'.
> refresh
Getting processes' information...
Done.
> frequency
2200 MHz
>
```

If "frequency" returns something on mac M1, it means the PR fixed the issue.
